question: Question_10_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 4â12, justify your

simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions}.

The power series representation above is used to approximate
$\displaystyle \int_0^{1/4} \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx$. How many terms are
required to guarantee that the resulting approximation is within
$\displaystyle 10^{-5}$ of the exact value? Justify your answer.
sols:
By
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2013/Question_10_(a)}{part
(a)},

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{1/4} \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx & = \left.\left[\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}x^{3n+1}\right) + C\right]\right|_0^{1/4} \\
& = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3n+1}
\end{align*}

This is an alternating sum with

\[\displaystyle 
b_n = \frac{1}{3n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3n+1}.\]

Clearly $\displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq b_n$ and
$\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty} b_n = 0$. Then by Alternating Series
Remainder Theorem, the error in the approximation is bounded as follows:

\[\displaystyle 
|\text{error}| \leq b_{n+1}\]

Then we are guaranteed the error is less than $\displaystyle 10^{-5}$ if
$\displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq 10^{-5}$, that is, we must solve

\[\displaystyle 
 \frac{1}{3(n+1)+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3(n+1)+1} \leq 10^{-5} = \frac{1}{10^5}.\]

For $\displaystyle n+1=1$,

\[\displaystyle 
 \frac{1}{3+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3+1} = \frac{1}{4^5} > \frac{1}{10^5}\]

so we do not have enough terms yet. For $\displaystyle n+1=2$,

\[\displaystyle 
 \frac{1}{3(2)+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3(2)+1} \leq \frac{1}{7}\frac{1}{16000} = \frac{1}{112000} < \frac{1}{10^5}\]

where we have used
$\displaystyle 4^7 = 2^{14} = 2^{10} \cdot 16 = 1024 \cdot 16 \geq 1000 \cdot 16 = 16000$
to approximate. Thus, $\displaystyle n+1=2$ is sufficient. Since the
series starts at 0, we need 2 terms (the $\displaystyle n=0$ and
$\displaystyle n=1$ term, specifically).
